infoTargets.name: Nobel prizes
infoTargets.information: Former NTH student Ivar Giæver recieved the nobel prize in physics in 1973. Former NTH student Lars Onsager was awarded the nobel prize in chemistry in 1968.

infoTargets.name: Nobel prize: Medicine
infoTargets.information: In 2014, brain researchers May-Britt and Edvard Moser were awarded the nobel prize in medicine or physiology alongside John O'Keefe from UCL.

infoTargets.name: Strategic reaserch
infoTargets.information: In the years 2014-2023 the strategic research areas of NTNU are sustainability, energy, oceans and health.

infoTargets.name: NTNU Sustainability
infoTargets.information: Research on the environmental, economic and social aspects of the development of society.

infoTargets.name: NTNU Energy
infoTargets.information: Focuses on development and integration of renewable and sustainable energy supply.

infoTargets.name: NTNU Oceans
infoTargets.information: Research on maritime transport, subsea exploration, and polar science and technology.

infoTargets.name: NTNU Health
infoTargets.information: Focus on health promotion, diagnostics and therapy, IT, welfare and organisation of health services.

infoTargets.name: Kahoot
infoTargets.information: Kahoot started as a masters project at NTNU.

infoTargets.name: Library
infoTargets.information: NTNU's libraries hold 2 million books. Its roots go back to 1768, making it Norway's oldest scientific library.

infoTargets.name: Students
infoTargets.information: There are 35638 registered students in Trondheim (2019), about a thrid of them study at Gløshaugen.
